bring something ↔ forward.translation[0]: to change an arrangement so that something happens sooner
The meeting’s been brought forward to Thursday.
to officially introduce plans etc for people to discuss
The government has brought forward new proposals to tackle the problem of increasing crime.
to record the result of a calculation so that it can be used in a further calculation
bring something ↔ forward.translation[1]: if you bring forward a meeting or other event that is going to take place in the future, you arrange for it to take place at an earlier time
The next departmental meeting has been brought forward to the 10th.
to move the total from a set of numbers that you are calculating onto the next page, so that you can add or take away other numbers from it
The balance brought forward from the previous bank statement is £356.78.
